fate: U.S. chain largely shuttered after The Musicland Group’s 2006 bankruptcy; many stores closed or converted to FYE under new ownership
summary: Mall-era music retailer known for deep CD/cassette selection, singles, and chart walls; most stores disappeared after Musicland’s 2006 bankruptcy and subsequent conversions.
overview_md:
**Sam Goody** was a U.S. music retail chain that turned browsing into a weekend ritual for generations of listeners. Founded in 1951 in New York City, the brand helped define mall-era music shopping with chart walls, listening posts, racks of singles, and deep selections of CDs, cassettes, and later DVDs. Knowledgeable staff, weekly ads, and in-store promotions made the stores a reliable place to discover new releases and pick up back-catalog staples.

Sam Goody became part of **The Musicland Group**, whose banners included Musicland and Suncoast Motion Picture Company. Through the 1980s and 1990s the chain expanded nationally, leaning into high-visibility mall locations where foot traffic stayed strong. But the model—prime rents and large physical-media inventory—was squeezed by big-box price competition and the digital shift (file sharing, paid downloads, and ultimately streaming). Margins tightened, traffic fell, and carrying a broad catalog became harder to justify.

In **2006**, after ownership changes and mounting losses, Musicland filed for Chapter 11; many **Sam Goody** stores were liquidated, while others were acquired and **converted to FYE** under Trans World Entertainment. The brand’s decline marked a wider transition away from physical media retail. For many, the Sam Goody name still evokes flipping through shrink-wrapped jewel cases, scanning staff picks, and comparing Tuesday new-release stickers with friends at the mall.

timeline.text: Sam Goody opens in New York City
Becomes part of The Musicland Group
Best Buy acquires The Musicland Group (parent of Sam Goody)
Ownership shifts as Musicland is sold; ongoing store rationalization
Musicland files Chapter 11; many Sam Goody stores close or are converted to FYE
